intro: Ypsilopus sarcodanthus, commonly known as the ghost orchid, is a rare and elusive flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its unique, delicate appearance with pale greenish-white flowers. The plant is epiphytic, meaning it grows on the surface of trees without deriving nutrients from them. It has a short, slender stem and produces small, showy blooms that are often hidden among the foliage. Due to its habitat specificity and declining populations, it is considered endangered and requires careful conservation efforts.
